content:
But are the jihadists of Islamic State really defeated, as he claims?

ON THE CAMPAIGN trail Donald Trump blew hot and cold on Syria. “Everybody that's touched the Middle East, they've gotten bogged down,” he warned in 2015. The following year he reconsidered. “We really have no choice. We have to knock out ISIS,” he said, using an acronym for Islamic State (IS). Those competing arguments have played out in the White House and Pentagon over the past two years.

On December 19th Mr Trump’s scepticism won out. “We have defeated ISIS in Syria, my only reason for being there during the Trump Presidency,” he tweeted. American troops are already coming home, “as we transition to the next phase of this campaign”, said Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary. Officials have not said when the withdrawal will be complete, but reports suggest it will happen by early 2019. The decision heralds a dramatic shift in the balance of power in Syria, which has been mired in war for nearly eight years.

American troops first arrived in Syria in large numbers in 2015. They were tasked with beating back IS, which had blitzed through eastern Syria and northern Iraq a year earlier, capturing a swathe of land the size of Britain. Declaring it a “caliphate”, the jihadists claimed to speak for all of the world’s Muslims. Today nearly all of their territory has been recaptured by local forces, many of whom teamed up with the Americans. In mid-December the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF), backed by America, captured Hajin in eastern Syria, the last town held by IS, after an intense months-long campaign.

About 2,000 Americans remain in Syria, mostly in the north, with some along Jordan’s border in the south. They guide airstrikes, hunt senior IS leaders and train the SDF, a predominantly Kurdish group of fighters who have done the lion’s share of the ground combat against IS. America’s presence was also intended to serve as a bulwark against Iran’s ambitions in the region. American officials believe that Iran’s Revolutionary Guard Corps seeks a land corridor running from Tehran to Beirut, so that it can more easily send arms to Hizbullah, its proxy in Lebanon.

Mr Trump has flirted with withdrawal before. “I want to get out,” he declared in April. His generals convinced him to stay and continue to build up local forces. Days later he bombed three government sites in Syria to punish the regime of Bashar al-Assad for using chemical weapons. American officials seemed to think they had won over Mr Trump. In September John Bolton, the president’s national security adviser, said, “We’re not going to leave [Syria] as long as Iranian troops are outside Iranian borders, and that includes Iranian proxies and militias.” Earlier this month Brett McGurk, America’s regional envoy, said, “I think it's fair to say Americans will remain on the ground after the physical defeat of the caliphate.” To do otherwise would be “reckless”, he said.

The fall of Hajin may have convinced Mr Trump that America’s job is done in Syria. He has shown little interest in helping to topple Mr Assad, who, with the backing of Russia and Iran, has all but defeated the rebels trying to unseat him.

But Mr Trump’s claim that IS is beaten is incorrect. The group still controls a handful of Syrian villages along the eastern bank of the Euphrates river and a pocket of desert on the other side. Even as its territory shrinks, the jihadists remain adept at launching hit-and-run attacks. They captured 30 Kurdish fighters in November. And on the other side of the border, in Iraq, IS has increased its attacks in the provinces of Kirkuk and Diyala. The numbers are fuzzy, but the group is thought still to have thousands of fighters. It continues to broadcast its propaganda widely. Many of the conditions that nurtured its insurgency—poverty, corruption and bad governance—remain.

Iran may also try to exploit America’s withdrawal by pushing its proxy militias further east, towards the border with Iraq. They will have more freedom to operate in the south, too, if America dismantles its special-forces base at al-Tanf. That could prompt Israel to act. It has already carried out scores of airstrikes on Iranian-backed forces in Syria.

The biggest losers from the American withdrawal are the Kurds, who face threats on all sides. They control swathes of north-eastern Syria, on the the border with Turkey, which considers the SDF part of a terrorist group. By occupying a strip of northern Syria, Turkey has prevented the Kurds from linking their eastern and western cantons. It has carried out two offensives against Kurdish militias since 2016. On December 12th it promised a third. Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the Turkish president, said Turkey would attack Kurdish fighters east of the Euphrates river within days. The presence of American troops in that area had, until now, deterred him.

With the threat of American retaliation gone, the brutal Mr Assad may also sniff an opportunity. He has long vowed to retake every inch of the country from the rebels, including the SDF. He may not even have to fight to get what he wants. The Kurds, who have held on-off talks with the regime for years, could cut a deal that swaps American protection for that offered by Mr Assad and his foreign backers. One thing is sure. America’s exit will not be the end of Syria’s woes.

My name had been dragged through the mire(= my reputation was ruined) .
我的名声受到了玷污。

ex: vt. 养育；鼓励；培植
n. 养育；教养；营养物

But, of course, there is some element of  in this equation.
但是 里面当然也存在一些后天培养的因素.
I think it is really cool that there is an organization like this to help nurture the creative spark in kids who have not just a dream, but an idea for how to make it real.
科技青训营专门帮助那些不仅有梦想，而且拥有能使梦想成真的点子的孩子门，培养他们的创造力，我觉得这样一个组织的存在实在是件非常酷的事情。
